Hi,

Well, I think I finally got it nailed down. I've been tinkering with
I=
an's method all morning trying to get the right parameters and
conditions f=
or raising and lowering the speciation threshold, but
nothing worked to my =
satisfaction. If I set a target of 10 species, I
could not get the threshol=
d to decrease slow enough to prevent jumps
from like 3 to 17 species within=
 one generation. And once you have too
many species, it's very hard to get =
rid of them. That's because
increasing the threshold only makes the first s=
pecie in line get
almost all offspring assigned to it as they can suddenly =
all be
matched to it's representative (because the threshold is too high).
=

So finally I have come up with a method that will always ensure that
there=
 are never more than the target amount of species and that all
chromosomes =
are distributed amoung the species as well as possible.
Firstly, I always k=
eep the species sorted by size. This is cheap to
maintain if you compare th=
e size of the specie you have just added a
new chromosome to with the speci=
e next in line and swap them (and if
necessary keep swapping) if the first =
has become bigger. (It does not
appear to be necessary to re-sort the speci=
es after removing all unfit
chromosomes before adding the offspring to main=
tain a good
distribution.) Secondly, when a new chromosome cannot be matche=
s with
any specie and we already have the target amount of species, I set t=
he
speciation threshold to the smallest distance between the new
chromosome=
 and any specie (the value of which, of course, I was
already keeping track=
 of while trying to find a suitable specie). Or
that minimum distance + 0.0=
01 if distances need to be strictly smaller
than the theshold, like in ANJI=
. Then I add the new chromosome to the
specie in which it now fits. Finally=
, you can even set the initial
speciation threshold to zero to get and keep=
 the target amount of
species from the first generation on.

I have not sea=
rched to see if others before me have already come up
with this method too,=
 but I hope anyone who was struggling with the
same problem can benefit fro=
m it. :)

Bas
